content: ++http://www.foxnews.com/politics/elections/2009/05/29/charges-black-panthers-dropped-obama/++ Charges brought against three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense under the Bush administration have been dropped by the Obama Justice Department, FOX News has learned. The charges stemmed from an incident at a Philadelphia polling place on Election Day 2008 when three members of the party were accused of trying to threaten voters and block poll and campaign workers by the threat of force -- one even brandishing what prosecutors call a deadly weapon. [Let 'em or anybody else try their pel*si where my neighbors and I vote; they'll not come back to try it again, I am confident.] The three black panthers, "Minister King" Samir Shabazz [title like a Grand Wizard], Malik Zulu Shabazz and Jerry Jackson were charged in a civil complaint in the final days of the Bush administration with violating the voter rights act by using coercion, threats and intimidation. Shabazz allegedly held a nightstick or baton that prosecutors said he pointed at people and menacingly tapped it. Prosecutors also say he "supports racially motivated violence against non-blacks and Jews."[But that's okay by the obamanation.] The Obama administration won the case last month, but moved to dismiss the charges on May 15. [Wonder what the quid pro quo was?] - - - - - - - - - - Hey, instead of pursuing justice for the convicted criminals, the obamanation and its lock-step minions can spend more time harrassing law-abiding citizens, especially military veterans. Good use of taxpayer money and a sure-fire way to ensure national security in the brave new world (no, cowardly old--pre-Constitution--world) of the obamanation, yowzah, baby.

[Let 'em or anybody else try their pel*si where my neighbors and I vote; they'll not come back to try it again, I am confident.] The three black panthers, "Minister King" Samir Shabazz [title like a Grand Wizard], Malik Zulu Shabazz and Jerry Jackson were charged in a civil complaint in the final days of the Bush administration with violating the voter rights act by using coercion, threats and intimidation. Philidephia is a funny place. Interesting that Fox News finally has a story about voter intimidation to report. I wonder where they've been? quote: "Voter terrorism" For decades, Republicans have mounted highly organized operations to discourage minorities from voting. Experts say there's no reason to believe this year's presidential campaign will be any different. By Farhad Manjoo Sep 21, 2004 | Philadelphia's 2003 mayoral election did not set especially high standards for civic discourse in the city where American democracy was born. Talking to Philadelphians about the bitter contest between John Street, the African-American incumbent Democrat, and Sam Katz, the white Republican challenger, is like discussing an election in some upstart Latin American democracy. During the course of the race, Street's office was bugged by the FBI, a Katz field office was "firebombed" by an unlit Molotov cocktail, and on Election Day, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported, 84 voting-related incidents were called in to police, including "assaults, disturbances, threats, harassment, vandalism" and one bona fide "polling-place brawl." Amid the general ugliness of the race, though, there's one incident that Democrats in the city remember with a distinct sense of unease. The story, which was first reported by The American Prospect in February, and has since been broadcast by activist groups like MoveOn.org, goes like this: In an attempt to intimidate African-Americans and deter them from showing up at the polls, the Katz campaign, or one of its associates, put together a team of men dressed in official-looking attire -- dark suits, lapel pins bearing insignia of federal or local law-enforcement agencies -- and sent them into areas of the city with large black populations. According to Sherry Swirsky, a local antitrust attorney who is active in Democratic politics and who worked as an election monitor that day, the men carried clipboards and drove around in unmarked black vans. "Some of them were just driving around neighborhoods, looking menacing," Swirsky recalls. "But others were going up to voters and giving them misinformation about the kind of I.D. they needed in order to vote. The truth is, you don't need any I.D. to vote. But they were telling them they needed a major credit card, a passport or driver's license. They were telling them it was risky to vote if they had any outstanding child support bills. Imagine the menacing presence of a bunch of big white guys in black cars who look like they're law-enforcement people telling you all these things." "http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2004/09/21/intimidation/index.html" I guess organised mass campaigns are small stuff compared to two guys standing around doing nothing. Dave

The charges stemmed from an incident at a Philadelphia polling place on Election Day 2008 when three members of the party were accused of trying to threaten voters and block poll and campaign workers by the threat of force -- one even brandishing what prosecutors call a deadly weapon. [Let 'em or anybody else try their pel*si where my neighbors and I vote; they'll not come back to try it again, I am confident.] The three black panthers, "Minister King" Samir Shabazz [title like a Grand Wizard], Malik Zulu Shabazz and Jerry Jackson were charged in a civil complaint in the final days of the Bush administration with violating the voter rights act by using coercion, threats and intimidation. Shabazz allegedly held a nightstick or baton that prosecutors said he pointed at people and menacingly tapped it. Prosecutors also say he "supports racially motivated violence against non-blacks and Jews."[But that's okay by the obamanation.] The Obama administration won the case last month, but moved to dismiss the charges on May 15. Voter intimidation, whether done by Democrats or Republicans are based on math. You go to a district where your candidate is going to lose. Therefore, lowering the vote will benefit your candidate. You do NOT go to a district where your candidate is going to win. Holder dropped the case because He KNEW that any decent defense lawyer could make the same case as I did above (but a hell of a lot better) and no jury in the world would convict them. Dave

By Farhad Manjoo Sep 21, 2004 | Philadelphia's 2003 mayoral election did not set especially high standards for civic discourse in the city where American democracy was born. Talking to Philadelphians about the bitter contest between John Street, the African-American incumbent Democrat, and Sam Katz, the white Republican challenger, is like discussing an election in some upstart Latin American democracy. During the course of the race, Street's office was bugged by the FBI, a Katz field office was "firebombed" by an unlit Molotov cocktail, and on Election Day, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported, 84 voting-related incidents were called in to police, including "assaults, disturbances, threats, harassment, vandalism" and one bona fide "polling-place brawl." Amid the general ugliness of the race, though, there's one incident that Democrats in the city remember with a distinct sense of unease. The story, which was first reported by The American Prospect in February, and has since been broadcast by activist groups like MoveOn.org, goes like this: In an attempt to intimidate African-Americans and deter them from showing up at the polls, the Katz campaign, or one of its associates, put together a team of men dressed in official-looking attire -- dark suits, lapel pins bearing insignia of federal or local law-enforcement agencies -- and sent them into areas of the city with large black populations. According to Sherry Swirsky, a local antitrust attorney who is active in Democratic politics and who worked as an election monitor that day, the men carried clipboards and drove around in unmarked black vans. "Some of them were just driving around neighborhoods, looking menacing," Swirsky recalls. "But others were going up to voters and giving them misinformation about the kind of I.D. they needed in order to vote. The truth is, you don't need any I.D. to vote. But they were telling them they needed a major credit card, a passport or driver's license. They were telling them it was risky to vote if they had any outstanding child support bills. Imagine the menacing presence of a bunch of big white guys in black cars who look like they're law-enforcement people telling you all these things." "http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2004/09/21/intimidation/index.html" I guess organised mass campaigns are small stuff compared to two guys standing around doing nothing. Dave
quote: Originally posted by RRR52: ++http://www.foxnews.com/politics/elections/2009/05/29/charges-black-panthers-dropped-obama/++ Charges brought against three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense under the Bush administration have been dropped by the Obama Justice Department, FOX News has learned. The charges stemmed from an incident at a Philadelphia polling place on Election Day 2008 when three members of the party were accused of trying to threaten voters and block poll and campaign workers by the threat of force -- one even brandishing what prosecutors call a deadly weapon. [Let 'em or anybody else try their pel*si where my neighbors and I vote; they'll not come back to try it again, I am confident.] The three black panthers, "Minister King" Samir Shabazz [title like a Grand Wizard], Malik Zulu Shabazz and Jerry Jackson were charged in a civil complaint in the final days of the Bush administration with violating the voter rights act by using coercion, threats and intimidation. Shabazz allegedly held a nightstick or baton that prosecutors said he pointed at people and menacingly tapped it. Prosecutors also say he "supports racially motivated violence against non-blacks and Jews."[But that's okay by the obamanation.] The Obama administration won the case last month, but moved to dismiss the charges on May 15. [Wonder what the quid pro quo was?] - - - - - - - - - - Hey, instead of pursuing justice for the convicted criminals, the obamanation and its lock-step minions can spend more time harrassing law-abiding citizens, especially military veterans. Good use of taxpayer money and a sure-fire way to ensure national security in the brave new world (no, cowardly old--pre-Constitution--world) of the obamanation, yowzah, baby.
